ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments:
Also live discussion section.
Also live q&a session.
We had a pre-recorded podcast twice a week and a live Q&A session once a week in addition to a discussion section.
live virtual Q/A session with instructor, live virtual seminar for section discussion
Two podcast lectures + one live Q&A with Professor North and the TAs + one discussion section
recorded podcasts; virtual sections with TF and Q&A with prof.
The lecture was a podcast.
Zoom Q+As and section
Two weekly live sections: one with TF, one with  prof
The course's virtual version included two weekly, hour-long recorded asynchronous podcasts, and an additional synchronous, weekly, live hour-long Q&A session and hour-long discussion section.
Recorded audio lecture with weekly synchronous Q&A and section
Everything was online, via Zoom

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Understanding of basic political theory.
Understanding of a wide array of texts from ~17th - 21st centuries. 
Understanding of new methods of reading and evaluating texts grounded in political theory.
I gained insight and appreciation for the texts of other cultures that I had never read works from before.

Knowledge of centrism, its definition and structures of feelings, and why the center continues to hold the power in political discussion over either left & right. Also history on where left/right/center originate, important literary texts that influence centrist structures of feeling, and contextualization of all this content with modern social justice issues
I read a variety of political literature and learned a lot, and I mean, a LOT about centrism.
How to rethink through great works through the lens of centrism

I learned how to understand and analyze literature as a site for political struggle, reflection, and regulation. Our reading of Burke (which served as a key figure in our understanding of conservatism) taught me how to better appreciate vertical theories of society/government, linking our aesthetic tastes with our political sensibilities. Professor North gave a series of absolutely incredible lectures of Woolf's "Mrs. Dalloway", performing the art of close reading to its highest degree. Though this class is listed in the English department, I learned a solid amount of political science from a particularly leftist perspective, which I appreciated. Professor North also demonstrated for us analysis in the style of Raymond Williams's "Keywords", a skill that I imagine I'll turn to often in future research and writing. Towards the end of the course, we had the opportunity to explore more "distant" political systems distant in the sense of different from Western models. Namely, we thought a lot about and discussed the system of stateless democracy (if you could call it that) of Australian Aboriginals super interesting!
I learned how to analyse centrist sensibilities in literature from the 18th to 20th centuries.
Close reading, writing, and development of my ability to think critically.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Novel and interesting course structure and trajectory.
Effective assessment structure.
Engaging lectures and useful discussion sections.
Q&A could be replaced by longer live lectures that include time for questions at the end.

This course is a great course to take to think critically about political literature and the intersection between politics and aesthetics. It did not have that high of a workload, so it was a fun and manageable fifth class.

Strengths: virtual lectures were helpful to watch on our own time so we could come to Q/A with pre-thought out questions. Organization of centrism definitions in the beginning, then history of its evolution, and finally its context within modern political issues and where to go from here was very useful. 
Weaknesses: lectures, Q/A, and section did make the course time per week substantial, though not too much time was spent outside on work, since there are only 2 essays and a few weekly response assignments, on top of reading texts.

Professor North is super knowledgeable about the course material, and the TFs were great as well. While I love learning about political literature, I do wish we had focused on Social Justice through the lens of the more technical aspects of writing. Overall, a really fun class.

The course was an interesting way to look at the modern political and aesthetic conversation through the lens of a left-wing /socialist critic. I think looking at some of the other ways of thinking about the modern world might have helped us understand the complexities of it rather than just one argument about it.

This course did a really good job of making us think more critically about different writers/thinkers. But, I think we could've delved more into the "social justice" and historical aspects of the course.

Weaknesses: none.
Strengths: more than I could describe, but I'll try. First, Professor North is simply amazing; undoubtedly one of the best educators I've ever had. All of the teaching fellows were also lovely! We had the especially unique and beneficial opportunity of having a TF dedicated as a writing tutor specifically for this course. The course was also well and creatively adapted to remote learning, so kudos to the teaching team for that! The readings for this class were great and interesting! Great feedback on essays as well.

Strengths: Professor North is brilliant, kind, and funny, and the teaching fellows are great! The syllabus is also very interesting and, while it includes big name authors, also includes some more obscure ones that I most likely would not have read if I hadn't taken this course. I also like how the class mixed readings in theory and fiction, most of which were very interesting and genuinely good reads. I really enjoyed the way the course focused on the idea of centrism, and how it tied together the class and its arc.
Weaknesses: I don't think the virtual format was good for this course. The podcast + Q&A combo meant 3 hours of listening to Professor North speak every week, which was a bizarre and unnecessary way to conduct a literature class that was so ripe for discussion. Additionally, feedback was only given on the midterm and final papers, which made gauging expectations and grading very difficult, and also provided few chances to get to display improvement or to actually act on the feedback that was given. Lastly, I felt like the amount I learned over the semester decreased substantially after the first couple of weeks, and I would have liked to see more of a connection to the "social justice" part of the class, which was surprisingly not very prevalent.

Strengths--reading list is amazing. It was really interesting to analyze the intersection of politics and literature. Feedback on essays is constructive and abundant, which was great.
Weaknesses: I think the course would benefit from reducing the number of lectures at the beginning on contemporary political movements and moving more quickly to the literature--the way the course stands, the reading gets really heavy in the latter half of the course, and could be more evenly distributed if we started on the literature a bit sooner. I also would have liked to read literature from the 19th century, which we skipped over. I also would have liked to read some more political philosophy at the beginning other than Wallerstein's work (which is of course interesting, but I think having perspectives from other theorists would have been helpful too). The Q&A sessions also often dragged on; the sessions where there was more discussion were more interesting, so perhaps incorporating more discussion would make the sessions more engaging

The strengths were the Professor and the Teaching Fellows.  They were potent and powerful in their delivery and engagement. Additionally, the diverse works of literature that we covered in the scope of the course was significant.  In fact, it was amazing. The only weakness was the remote nature of the course.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The podcast structure was not the best because they were only available for 24 hours. This was difficult with time differences and schedules because the podcasts did not "air" on the scheduled course day. I had a really heavy course load on one of the days the podcast aired, and sometimes it was really difficult to make sure I could listen to and take notes on the podcast on that day. However, because the podcast was only available that day, it had to be heard then.
virtual lectures were great to allow students to engage on their own time despite time zones, especially audio lectures that we could listen to while doing other activities

I liked the flexibility of the podcast lectures, but sometimes felt intimidated to participate in the live Q+A! One thing to consider could be a question form before each Q+A where we each have to submit questions if we don't want to speak in the Q+A.
I really loved having the lectures in podcast form.

I liked that lectures were asynchronous but there were also synchronous components like section. I wish however that the Q+A could've maybe been combined withs section into a larger session with breakout groups.

I really loved how the class was adapted. One note for improvement: because the lectures were just audio, I usually listened to them away from my desk, and thus didn't take notes. That, combined with the fact that lectures were taken down after 24 hours, made it difficult to have material to look back on.
The podcast format of the lecture was great--it was good to get away from screens to listen to the lectures and take notes away from a computer.
I believe that the course was about as good as one could expect from the circumstances.  The teaching staff really went out of their way to respond to the group and individual needs.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. This course is unique among the English courses I've taken in its breadth and its method. If you're interested in the intersection of politics and literature, take this class.

I would definitely recommend this course to others. It is not very work or time intensive with only two papers throughout the semester. The reading on the whole was really enjoyable. Professor North is very kind and accommodating, and his lectures are engaging. He is a bit rambly, but it didn't inhibit me from enjoying the course.

Yes!!! Very practical knowledge to understand what forces are working in modern political discourse, even in casual interviews or tweets to election debates. Even if you don't have a lot of polisci or literature experience, this course is a great to learn about both, and is very inclusive to students of all experience levels
Yes! This class was fun and interesting, and Professor North really knows what he's talking about :)
Yes! Professor North is a great lecturer and really pushes you to think deeper about literature in social contexts

This course was easily the best I took this semester I loved it! The material and readings were all incredibly interesting. Professor North is equally fantastic: not only is he an incredibly knowledgeable scholar, but also a deeply caring, sympathetic, and generous person. Throughout the semester, he made it a priority to connect with us students and to hear our thoughts on the material. Joe mentioned that the material of this class is an active area of research for him, so it was especially exciting to be able to be part of that. The TFs were likewise great and a joy to discuss with and learn from. For all those reasons, I recommend this class to any student without any reservations. Please, take this class!

I would recommend taking this class in person, but I would not recommend taking it virtually. Professor North was great and clearly wanted to connect with us and discuss, but I think the virtual setting just made that really difficult and caused him to speak more "at" us than I assume he normally would.

Yes, though do note that the class (as it stands) focuses on tracing centrism in literature throughout the centuries--a topic that I found interesting, but I would understand if one didn't find it so.

I would most certainly recommend this course to other students.  It was a door, opening to a whole world of political thought, that I was unaware of.  The nuances of the readings, combined with the lectures were very enriching.
